Article.ArticleTitle: Elevated CO<sub>2</sub> increases biomass and tuber yield in potato even at high ozone concentrations.

AbstractText: •  Changes in the growth and yield of field-grown potato (Solanum tuberosum cv. Bintje) induced by season-long elevated CO<sub>2</sub> and/or ozone concentrations are reported. •  Open-top chambers and unchambered field plots were used to examine crop responses to three CO<sub>2</sub> (ambient, 550 and 680 µmol mol<sup>-1</sup> ) and two ozone (ambient and 65 nmol mol<sup>-1</sup> , 8 h d<sup>-1</sup> seasonal mean) treatments applied throughout the 105 d growing season. •  Elevated CO<sub>2</sub> increased both above- and below-ground biomass at intermediate and final harvests. Tuber yield at final harvest was increased by c. 40% due to an increase in mean tuber weight rather than tuber number; tuber yield did not differ significantly between the 550 and 680 µmol mol<sup>-1</sup> CO<sub>2</sub> treatments. Elevated ozone had no significant effect on growth or yield except for the largest size category of tubers, despite extensive visible foliar injury. Significant CO<sub>2</sub>  × ozone interactions were detected only for senescent leaf number and green leaf ratio. •  Elevated CO<sub>2</sub> increases biomass and tuber yield in S. tuberosum cv. Bintje even at high ozone concentrations; these findings are discussed in relation to predicted future atmospheric changes.
